Ken, I have to mention that Tyler was inspired by Torsten Reil and 
Phil Hu=
sbands about their work on the same stuff. They used fully 
connected CTRNN=
s. No crossover and fixed genome size. Well, it is 
just like the opposite =
to the NEAT philosophy about the problem. I 
examined his .ne file, and he =
made the add_link and add_node 
probabilities to 0.00. :) 
Well this is NEA=
T in the weight-range sense only :)  
What about topology? That was not men=
tioned anywhere. 
In fact, Reil and Husbands are the people founded Natural=
Motion? :) 
I know that a CTRNN can generate any dynamic behaviour, but put=
ting 
it into HyperNEAT's hands is changing the whole thing! Now I can 
spe=
cify any time constant range and so on. I don't care about 
mutation powers=
 anymore. This is handled by the activation functions 
and the scale factor=
 I specify. 
The power of this indirection is getting to our view. I see th=
at 
CTRNN networks exhibit patterns as complex as their CPPN is. Well, 
thi=
s is cool! 

Peter


--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanl=
ey@...> wrote:
>
> Peter and Steve, the way I would approach this problem i=
s to start 
> with the simplest possible model and get it working before mo=
ving 
to 
> more complex or biologically plausible ones.  It's interesting =
to 
> note that Tyler Streeter evolved his biped with no inputs!  He was 
>=
 trying to see if a fully recurrent network on its own with no 
inputs 
> c=
ould produce a temporal walking pattern.  Of course that makes the 
> probl=
em quite difficult, and giving some feedback (i.e. inputs) 
makes 
> the pr=
oblem easier.  However, too many inputs could tip the 
> difficulty back in=
 the other direction.  In any case, my approach 
to 
> a hard problem is al=
ways to first see if I can do the easiest 
version 
> of it.
> 
> By the wa=
y, about Natural Motion, most of their current stuff 
> probably is mainly =
hand-coded.  They started out using CTRNNs but 
> they moved on the scripti=
ng and other things as Peter mentioned.  
So 
> they are a very difficult t=
arget to match with evolution alone.
> 
> By the way, thanks for the encour=
aging words on NEAT and HyperNEAT.
> 
> ken
>

hey have modeled elastic muscles and 
so

o test HyperNEAT. I see that NEAT 
and

odels.. just suck!
